Expectation1: Follow safety protocols to prevent accidents and injuries on site
Situation1: Before starting structural work, the carpenter needs to inspect and maintain tools and equipment to ensure safety and efficiency
Expectation2: Prepare sermons and deliver weekly messages during Shabbat services.
Situation2: A sermon must be delivered for a High Holiday service, which the entire congregation is expected to attend.
Story: I stood in my workshop, the scent of sawdust thick in the air, my hands running over the worn handles of my tools. The beams for the new community center needed to be cut and fitted today, but before I could even think of starting, I had to inspect every saw, every drill, every blade. Safety was non-negotiable; one careless moment could mean disaster for me or my crew. Yet, as I checked the teeth of my circular saw, my phone buzzed with a reminder: the High Holiday sermon. The congregation would gather tonight, expecting words of wisdom and comfort. I hadn’t written a single line. My mind spun with the weight of both worlds—my duty to keep my team safe, and my responsibility to guide my community spiritually. Each role demanded my full attention, but time was slipping away. I stared at the tools, then at my notes, feeling the pressure build inside me, torn between the calluses on my hands and the words in my heart.
